original_content:
The first clue was that a number of locomotives started malfunctioning with exactly 1,000,000 km on the odometer. And when the company with the contract for servicing them couldnt figure out why, they typed Polish hackers into a search engine, and found our heroes [Redford], [q3k], and [MrTick]. What follows is a story of industrial skullduggery, CAN bus sniffing, obscure reverse engineering, and heavy rolling stock, and a fantastically entertaining talk.
Cutting straight to the punchline, the manufacturer of the engines in question apparently also makes a lot of money on the service contracts, and included logic bombs in the firmware that would ensure that revenue stream while thwarting independent repair shops. They also included cheat codes that simply unlocked the conditions, which the Polish hackers uncovered as well. Perhaps the most blatant evidence of malfeasance, though, was that there were actually checks in some versions of the firmware that geofenced out the competitors repair shops.
We shouldnt spoil too much more of the talk, and theres active investigation and legal action pending, but the smoking guns are incredibly smoky. The theme of this years Chaos Communication Congress is Unlocked, and you couldnt ask for a better demonstration of why its absolutely in the public interest that hackers gotta hack. Of course, [Daniel Lange] and [Felix Domke]s reverse engineering of the VW Dieselgate ECU shenanigans, another all-time favorite, also comes to mind.
title: 「ロケット突入！謎の故障、ポーランドハッカーが解明」
body: 数台の機関車が100万km走行後に故障し始めた。修理業者は原因が分からず、ポーランドのハッカーを検索すると、[Redford]、[q3k]、[MrTick]という人々を見つけた。興味深いお話は、産業スカルダギリ、CANバススニッフィング、逆向きエンジニアリングの話からなる。製造業者はサービス契約で多くの利益を得ており、ファームウェアには収益源を確保し独立修理業者を阻止するためのロジックボムが含まれていた。また、ポーランドのハッカーが解析したチートコードも含まれていた。さらに、競合他社の修理業者を地理的に制限するチェックもあった。本件には調査と法的措置が待たれている。今年のChaos Communication Congressのテーマは「アンロック」で、ハッカーがハックすることが一般的に利益になる理由がよくわかる話だ。もちろん、VWディーゼルゲートのECUシャナンギンズの逆向きエンジニアリングも思い起こさせる。
